label: The Evil Wedding of Stanton Drew
column5: During a Saturday wedding party at Stanton Drew
column6: a pious harpist refused to play past midnight to respect the Sabbath
column7: and a mysterious piper took his place. The piper
column9: enchanted the dancers into stone with his tunes
column11: waiting for him to return and release them.

label: The Church the Devil Stole
column5: In the village near Brent Tor
column6: the Devil stole a newly built church during a dark autumn night
column7: placing it atop the hill to mock the villagers. However
column8: the villagers summoned a bishop who dedicated the church on the hill to St. Michael
column9: resulting in the Archangel defeating the Devil and securing the church's position.

label: Pentre-Cwrt Folk and the Devil
column7: the devil planned to drown the villagers by damming the River Teivy
column8: but a clever cobbler thwarted his plan by convincing him that the distance was too great
column9: causing the devil to abandon his effort. The pile of earth discarded by the devil still marks the spot today

label: The Devil and Llanarth Church
column5: A tale from Llanarth tells of a night when the village was disturbed by mysterious noises from the church belfry
column6: believed to be caused by the Devil himself. The local vicar confronted the Devil
column7: causing him to flee in haste and fall among the gravestones
column8: leaving visible marks on a stone still present today.

label: The Welsh Origins of the Jack-o'-Lantern
column6: the legend of the jack-o'-lantern involves Sion Dafydd tricking a devil multiple times
column7: eventually escaping by clinging to an apple tree and transforming into a fairy. Sion's cleverness and the devil's stupidity are central to the tale
column8: which ties his transformation to the notorious village of Rhiwgyfylchi

label: The Devil's Pulpit
column5: In a tale set in Wales
column6: the devil is said to have interacted with monks of Tintern Abbey by preaching from a rocky outcrop known as the Devil's Pulpit
column7: only to be driven away by a surprise dousing of holy water. The superstition that chalked doorsteps can keep evil at bay underscores the narrative's theme of folklore and beliefs about the devil's presence in the region.
